How should we differentiate our products and marketing efforts? How should we hire employees who are highly creative to succeed in an AI-driven world, who can think beyond patterns and leverage AI intelligence? How can such people compete with AI? AI doesn’t care about your Cannes Lions. It cares about results. It thinks in patterns and learns in seconds. html:
Don’t just make things— midwife things

How can creative leaders protect imagination in an AI-saturated world?

Recently, I was speaking with a CEO of a product company, and he asked me a question: “If AI can find 17 versions of your idea in 2 seconds…It’s not an idea. It’s a remix. How should we differentiate our products and marketing efforts? How should we hire employees who are highly creative to succeed in an AI-driven world, who can think beyond patterns and leverage AI intelligence? How can such people compete with AI? AI doesn’t care about your Cannes Lions. It cares about results. It thinks in patterns and learns in seconds. It doesn’t need coffee or compliments.”

Here are some insights from the conversation.

Revenues of creative agencies are tumbling.

Today, clients are increasingly choosing to invest in artificial intelligence rather than traditional marketing methods. Sir Martin Sorrell’s S4 Capital just reported an 11.4% drop in Q1 sales. It reduced its workforce by 7%, or 541 roles, to 7,166 as of last year. It is an indication of a massive change that is underway in the industry. This is despite the fact that 50% of customers find AI-generated ads a turn-off. The industry has begun discussing the integration of computational power with human creativity…
